summary.topic: you all came here with the goal to figure out how to go full-time on your idea.
summary.summary: you all came here to figure out how to go full-time on your idea. assuming that goal hasn’t changed, from what i've seen, some of you will achieve it.

summary.topic: some of you will figure it out within the 11-week window called sf2, but most will figure it out after leaving.
summary.summary: figure it out within this short 11-week window we call sf2. it's four weeks less than a college semester, but most of you will likely figure it out after you leave. it might take 6 months, 9 months, or even a year, but i have no doubt you all will.

summary.topic: you will figure it out if you don't give up on your goal, but it won't happen by itself.
summary.summary: if you don't give up on your goal, success won't just happen by itself. you'll have to take certain actions while you're currently learning a lot.

summary.topic: right now, you're learning about focus, asking for help, finding true fans, and selling authentically.
summary.summary: you're learning to focus, ask for help, find true fans, and sell authentically. you're also picking up a lot subconsciously through this process. but if i had to pick one thing that separates all of you from others, it's...

summary.topic: the main thing that separates you from your goals is making good decisions.
summary.summary: your goals are about making good decisions, so that's what we're focusing on.

summary.topic: we'll talk about making good decisions today, and I'm here to help you do that.
summary.summary: i'm here to help you and so is the rest of the team. we're just a plus to your decision-making abilities, but we also want to teach you to fish so you're not reliant on us. i'm going to teach you eight principles to do that.

summary.topic: we'll teach you eight principles to help you make better decisions on your own.
summary.summary: help you make better decisions on your own so in the early days of building you actually make good decisions

summary.topic: in the early days, decisions like platform choice or target market don't matter much; just take action.
summary.summary: just take action and gain momentum when starting out, instead of agonizing over decisions like posting to instagram or tiktok, or selling to businesses or consumers. these decisions might feel significant, but what really matters is your internal process for making them. don't overthink it, just pick one and move forward.

summary.topic: agonizing over small decisions means your decision-making process needs work.
summary.summary: if you decide something because you realize it doesn't matter much, your process is probably good. the process itself needs sharpening and honing. your decision-making process likely needs work otherwise.

summary.topic: a good decision-making process needs to be sharpened over your life, and it's about judgment.
summary.summary: you first gather data, then you apply your judgment, and then you make a decision. it’s like reading a menu, seeing what sounds good, and then ordering. most of your energy is spent on the judgment part, which is what really matters.

summary.topic: judgment is the lens we see data through to make decisions.
summary.summary: data acts like a lens we use to make decisions. just like when i make a pourover and intensely judge the coffee to figure out how to improve it next time. that judgment is essential for better results.

summary.topic: good judgment is what tells you to hire an intern, pick a track, or accept an event gig.
summary.summary: judgment helps you decide whether to hire the intern, choose a track for your reel, or accept a DJ gig for a 200 person event despite having no experience. it highlights the importance of making thoughtful, impactful decisions.

summary.topic: CEOs are paid for their sound judgment to make good decisions for many people.
summary.summary: some ceos get paid millions for their sound judgment, making decisions that impact many. similarly, artists earn big for creating what people want. good judgment is the most valuable trait, especially when the long-term is uncertain.

summary.topic: our first principle is when the long-term is unclear, make good short-term decisions.
summary.summary: declan and derek started strong with their ai study app, making 20-25k, but they're unsure about the company's direction. if you're uncertain about the long-term, focus on good short-term decisions: look at what you've learned, consider small steps, maintain your current progress, and ask your users for feedback. this buys you time to figure out your next move.

summary.topic: focus on improving your numbers now, regardless of future decisions.
summary.summary: focus on immediate improvements to boost numbers no matter your future decisions. with short-term gains, whether you sell or continue running the business, you'll benefit. aim for traction now and make other decisions later; even seemingly successful opportunities like the dubai government deal may not be right if they conflict with your current flexibility and growth phase.

summary.topic: second principle: quickly weigh potential upside versus downside.
summary.summary: cons you know is a straightforward way to weigh potential upsides versus downsides. for example, cat asked me the other day if she should DJ a party.

summary.topic: example: cat was unsure about DJing a party; we evaluated upside (networking) vs. downside (embarrassment).
summary.summary: brian johnson does everyone know who brian johnson is by now cool so i'm not that good at DJing yet and might embarrass build space which concerns her a lot, though i don't think she needs to be. pros are that many people get to know you; cons are potential embarrassment. we're usually our own harshest critics, and others probably don't notice the things we're worried about. thinking about the upside versus downside risk, the benefits usually outweigh the potential embarrassment, so just go for it.

summary.topic: another example: kareem wondered whether to pivot his business; we looked at the market and margins.
summary.summary: he's doing well with his current food truck service but considers pivoting to selling foot traffic data, which interests him more despite being at zero. advice: keep the food truck service going, maybe split focus 60/40 until the foot traffic data gains traction. consider market potential, margins, and personal excitement vs. the downside of the unknown. making big decisions becomes clearer by weighing pros and cons. straightforward, any questions?

summary.topic: principle three: if your decision is emotional, don't pretend it's logical.
summary.summary: if your decision is emotional, don't pretend it's logical. be honest about why you're making the decision, whether it's due to impatience or something else. if a bold move succeeds, great; if not, at least you'll recognize it was impatience.

summary.topic: sometimes all you need is a break rather than making a significant decision.
summary.summary: need a break, just two days off, and then i'm totally fine. simple as that.

summary.topic: understand why you're making a decision, whether it's impatience or a need for change.
summary.summary: you need to understand your emotional drivers to make better choices. for critical decisions, take your time, seek advice, and be objective. if a choice keeps resurfacing, it's a sign to address it seriously. mundane decisions can be guided by instinct, but significant ones warrant more careful consideration.

summary.topic: principle four: when in doubt, do the math.
summary.summary: kieran and mi are developing a b2b cloud services platform for managing cloud using code. they recently came up with another idea and asked if it was worth pursuing. my answer was sort of unclear.

summary.topic: example: use a spreadsheet to estimate revenue and costs for a new idea.
summary.summary: make a spreadsheet to estimate demand, pricing, costs, and delivery capacity. putting numbers to these ideas helps you be objective and approach things mathematically. it might even reveal whether it's a $50,000 idea or a $10 million idea.

summary.topic: doing the math helps you see if an idea is worth pursuing.
summary.summary: we constantly run numbers on around 100 business models to quickly determine their viability, often in just 5-10 minutes. for example, assessing whether selling merch is worth it involves calculating costs, margins, and delivery logistics. if ryan wants to make $4K from his clothing brand, he should analyze the cost, sales, and possible price adjustments—this could mean selling 160 shirts at $25 each or 8 leather jackets at $500 each, depending on his strategy and audience.

summary.topic: principle five: doing more than one thing at a time will likely result in failure.
summary.summary: making eight jackets in a month is likely more feasible than making 160 shirts considering the time investment needed. this exercise helps to reassess and potentially increase pricing for efficiency. tackling more than one significant task at a time often leads to failure due to divided focus, even if there is momentum or a team involved. doing one thing well typically garners better results than spreading oneself too thin.

summary.topic: focus on one thing, even if you have momentum or a team; split focus often dilutes effectiveness.
summary.summary: we discussed the difficulty of multitasking on two major projects simultaneously. it was agreed that while switching between tasks might feel productive and offer a break, it's often a sign of indecision or lack of conviction. ultimately, focusing on one primary objective can lead to better outcomes, especially when it comes to significant endeavors like building a startup or developing an artist career.

summary.topic: principle six: time is a form of currency, treat it as an investment in your decisions.
summary.summary: decisions are often complex and require careful consideration. it's important to weigh all options and potential outcomes. acting impulsively can lead to mistakes and regret.

summary.topic: evaluate how you spend your time, whether on work, networking, or breaks.
summary.summary: time is a precious, non-renewable resource that should be managed wisely. consider how you allocate your hours each week, whether it's building features, fixing bugs, or networking, and understand that your outputs are directly proportional to your time investment. always evaluate if an activity is worth your time, and remember that both time and energy levels can impact productivity and decision-making.

summary.topic: principle seven: assign probabilities to your decisions.
summary.summary: assign probabilities to make better decisions. for example, working 40 hours a week at a salaried job gives you a 100% chance of making 100k a year, while spending 60 hours a week painting art offers a 50% chance of making 30k because it's harder to sell art.

summary.topic: weigh your time and effort against the likelihood of achieving successful outcomes.
summary.summary: when evaluating opportunities, you can’t just focus on potential outcomes; you must consider their probabilities. for example, a 10% chance of making $10 million in five years or an 80% chance of closing a $20K sales deal should be quantified to grasp their true value. this approach aids decision-making by providing a clearer, though sometimes speculative, understanding of the odds and potential rewards involved.

summary.topic: principle eight: you'll never know if a decision was good or bad until much later.
summary.summary: you'll never know if a decision was good or bad until later. a good short-term result can come from a bad long-term decision and vice versa. life is complex, so just aim to learn.

summary.topic: life is complex; aim to learn and improve as much and as fast as possible.
summary.summary: improve quickly using learned principles, take your best guess, and that's it. a short-term mistake like leaving a job can feel bad initially due to loss of income but can be a good long-term decision; you just won't know right away.

summary.topic: focus on taking your best guess with the principles you've learned.
summary.summary: you never really know if a job was great or if your actions would've worked out better down the line. using tools and principles to make informed guesses adds some order to the chaos, but ultimately it's all just guessing. as for knowing when to chill, i'm never truly off; i find it hard to separate and fully relax.
